post.author: mikebart
post.body: hi, thought i'd show some stuff ive been working on for quite a while now its based on an old brick building i photographed in sydney, i've been using 3dsmax to model the peices, I havent had alot of time lately for this but ill hopefully get alot done in the next few months as i should have more free time ill post some in game shots soon so that you can make more sense of them..

post.author: modern
post.body: Looks good. I like the organic stuff aswell. It will be interesting to see how you translate this work into Doom. Keep it up!

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
thanks man, Ive been following some of your work, very inspiring stuff

heres a few shots in game, all the building diffuse textures are baked directly from the high poly models, ill do the final touches in photoshop when ive finished the model.

post.author: Jack Rammsdell
post.body: wow that looks really good ingame

post.author: modern
post.body: Yeah, thats worked out real nice. I like the distress in the brick work. How about adding some moodier lighting?

post.author: BJA
post.body:
Wow, that looks incredible ingame
Texturing, modeling and geometry are really great.
How exactly did you do that ? you baked the diffuse texture on the highpoly models (without making a low poly version)?

post.author: Rayne
post.body: That's the quality mods should feature at this time

post.author: dirk
post.body: great work!

post.author: mikebart
post.body: BJA; this is the high-poly model and it has all the diffuse information as well as the geometry for the normal map, I started by making alot of small models like the plants, bricks, cement etc... and textured them, then baked the whole lot onto the low poly model in 3dsmax using the projection modifier. The only disadvantage to this aproach IMO is that theres not alot of tiling going on so these models are quite hungry on texture memory, but still, I like the effect.

post.author: dirk
post.body: realy nice, have you tryd the paralax shader, the result is convincing in all directions (displaying, performance ...)

post.author: Black Dog
post.body:
That looks very nice. It's a bit strange that the arches continue past their keystone without any support, and the lighting is also too strong as you can see detail being blown out on your lighter surfaces. Still, damn cool.

Are you just having a bit of fun here, or are there further plans?

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
thanks dirk, ill have a look at the paralax shader

I was waiting for someone to say that about the arches . The arches will be in place of the arches on the face of the building itself, so there will be a large hole with bricks and rubble piled up underneath, Ill do a few tests with different lighting soon, I just want to try and get the model complete first.
Im just playing around really, experimenting with max.

post.author: heXum
post.body: Eat your heart out, Gears of War!

post.author: dirk
post.body:
@mikebart: yes this projection mapping works realy awesome in max.

@hexim jup gears of war, rocks too.

if you hear ´nothing for a while from me, no worry lol, ill be back soon, lats in two years =D

see you

___

let the games start

post.body: why have you put only diffuse textures on the high poly models?

post.author: Kiltron
post.body: Looks good mikebart. I wonder what that would look like with some killer moonlighting and ambience.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
I only noticed this thread today but am now "watching" it

anyway, very cool use of modeling and texture work done in the d3 engine

post.author: Kiltron
post.body: Also I'm not sure what direction you're going to go with this, but it is coming out very well looking. Perhaps I can give you a bit of inspiration through a concept on what direction to take this?

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
Kristus wrote:
Intresting..

Anyway, I'm questioning the usefulness of the tool. Since it's so liberal in it's usage of polies, it's probably more work to optimize the model than it would be to make it manually.

although I haven't tried it, thats what I was thinking, but we could use it for inspiration in the design of some plant models.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
I think the Ivy generator would be useful for quickly generating highpoly models which could then be projected onto alpha planes for use in game engines.
In its current state I dont really think its optimised to be used in current gen realtime engines.
its pretty new though and Im sure it will be developed into something more useful for games, those guys are pretty clever over at, http://graphics.uni-konstanz.de/publikationen/ and alot of the stuff they do is actually for realtime environment simulations, so im sure they'l develope it further.

Lumpengnom; can you show us some wires and stats of the Ivy?


Tron wrote:

Since you have all the models though you can't not give us some ingame d3 engine shots, your initial tests looked fantastic!


Ill see how I go with that tron, its just that the time I spend exporting these models to doom3 and then tweaking things in the engine could be better spent building assets, I can usually predict how a model or a texture is going to look in doom3 anyway and I just dont feel the need to put them ingame at the moment but whatever engine I use ill always post my work here.

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body:
mikebart wrote:
Lumpengnom; can you show us some wires and stats of the Ivy?


Actually not from that example because i no longer have the file but it was around 70K Polys.

Here´s a wire of another one i generated:

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
thats pretty amazing eh, the vines could be projected to alpha planes but I havent found a way to project alpha planes themselves like for the leaves.
Is it modifiable at all? can you replace the single leaf with a cluster of leaves and then run the program at lesser iterations?

post.author: Kristus
post.body: yeah, you can set levers to how many leafs and stuff you get.

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body: It might be possible to tie this to a mel script that created layers of low poly target meshes, then group the polies created by this with each plane based on proximity. You could then bake to each plane and get something similar to the shell based fur shaders.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
I've been getting some stuff in game, thought id better do it now before I end up with 50 odd assets to port to quake4, despite what I said earlier about not bothering what a silly idea that was.
Its not showing the best fps there, nothing's optimised in regards to textures and it seems to drop about 10 fps when I take a screenshot for some reason, but im not too concerned about the stats at the moment, i should be able to optimise it later if I need to, to get it running decently. Also ill be giving all the assets from my wip to the guys at the Ground Zero mod so you'll probably get hold of them fairly soon to use in your maps.

post.author: g0th
post.body: Great stuff Mikebart

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body: That´s really amazing work. Many games (not just mods but also commercial games) fail to get the colors and contrasts right which makes games look either bland (FEAR) or too bright colored (Unreal). These colors and contrasts you´ve got in your work are next to perfect, imo.

post.author: Hostyle
post.body: Are these assets for a future playable level or just your 3d playground? If its just a graphics playground you should stick to 3dsmax and dont worry about speed or smth.

post.author: Tron
post.body: This is looking good.

post.author: m!chi:be
post.body:
Quote:
Anyway, I'm questioning the usefulness of the tool. Since it's so liberal in it's usage of polies, it's probably more work to optimize the model than it would be to make it manually.


Its not made for Realtime Games or such. Its for CG guys. and theres no problem wit hthe polycount.

post.author: Bo$bevok
post.body: nothing short of breathtaking...

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
Lumpengnom wrote:
That´s really amazing work. Many games (not just mods but also commercial games) fail to get the colors and contrasts right which makes games look either bland (FEAR) or too bright colored (Unreal). These colors and contrasts you´ve got in your work are next to perfect, imo.


Thanks, I really payed more attention to the colour's in this one after I felt my last building was a failure in regard to colour theory.
The only thing that looks a bit out in those images to me is the grass, but ill put in some pavement and girth in there instead.



Hostyle wrote:
Are these assets for a future playable level or just your 3d playground? If its just a graphics playground you should stick to 3dsmax and dont worry about speed or smth.


Im really just putting it in the game so that its ready for the ground zero mod, it'll have to be heavily modified to work I think, especially if we make it destructible.
I was just going to keep it in max initially, just because it looks better, with alpha shadows and soft shadows and all that but I was advised to put it ingame for good reason;
If I went for a job they'd want to see that I can work within the constraints of a game engine aswell as a 3d renderer.

post.author: Bo$bevok
post.body: you're gonna make it all destructable?!?! .....

post.author: heXum
post.body: I don't think I've chimed in and said how impressive that stuff is. Good work!

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
we're only really just been talking about it at the moment, discussing the best way to go about it, the only unique texture on the building is the arch which includes the ornament aswell, all the rest could be sized down to be quite small, but like i said it will need to be heavily modified to work.

@hexum; thx

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
heres some more shots of the new building, im gradualy converting it from high to low poly.

hi poly = 39891 tris, low poly = 1454. (thats just the ornament btw.)

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: very nice markbart. did you model by hand the curtains or use some automated tool to create the folds, waves? in blender we can attach wave modifiers to meshes which do a lot of the hard work for us, we just have to tweak a few parameters.

post.author: mikebart
post.body: theres a wave modifier in max too, I played around with it initialy but in the end i didnt use it, I moved all the vertexes by hand to create the folds and then subdivided the mesh

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: understood and thats even more impressive

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
its all low poly now, apart from the broken glass which needs a texture, im hoping it should all be under 2000 polys when its finished, its about 1700 at the moment. Ive also changed a few things with the bottom story I removed the tiles and widened the windows.

these are max renders just two omni lights, one with area shadows.

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body: lookin good! you might want to put a slot in the window pane where the glass sits. The parts with red brick showing through seems a little incongruous- the exposed bricks are too clean, yet also have a lot of depth in the grout compared to the other parts that're super smooth like glazed concrete. The orange in the brick and green in the leaves seem really saturated compared to the rest of the colors. The purplish cracking window pane is awesome.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
thanks guys,
i plan on adding grime/dirt maps to the diffuse using a blend in the doom3 shader, so ill leave the dirty details for later, for now im just concentrating on baking some base textures, ill be able to repeat the model several times and having several different grime/dirt maps should give me some good variation.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
Just a a small update, Ive added an ao pass and dirtmap to the diffuse texture of the ornament and arch.

Ive also been making some new plants, If anyone recognises what they are please let me know, I just spent about 1hr on google trying to identify them but couldnt find their name, it would be nice to name them something other than weed01 .




and here are some wires;

post.author: Tron
post.body: I'm really looking forward to seeing some more ingame shots. I am terrified of how much texture memory your project is going to use though.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
yeah so am I, they're all 2048 at the moment mainly just for the max renders I seriously need to upgrade my PC though.
I figure that by the time I finish this project we'll all be driving around in hover cars and the average PC will be well above the requirements to run my map .

I think rather than put it in doom3 though, I might just keep working on it in max and then decide on another engine later, see what comes out.
If etqw comes out with a UI shader program then I might stick with it but I know my way around UnrealEd enough to be able to put assets in there and I think its alot more user freindly than Doom3 and its selling licences like hot cakes.

post.author: Kristus
post.body:
I just made a quick test of it today. But the generator is not exactly very economic in it's use of polies. a small scrub, ended up at 4000 polies.

after I removed a bunch of the excessive branches, I got it down to about half though.

Since it's exporting to obj files, it's not harder to get it into Doom3, than it is to make any custom models for Doom3 really. (atleast it isn't for me, since I often use the export to obj function in Radiant to make the custom models seam up with the maps I've built)

But since you're using Blender (right) I don't know how well it support the .obj format.

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body:
I just did a test and it works but it´s a bit tricky.
I import the obj to Max, separate the leaves from the branches and export to ase.
The leaves work fine but i´m having trouble with the branches. I had to cut the branches into several smaller ase files because otherwise doom would simply hang.
Here´s a test image.

<edit>Blender handles obj fine.</edit>

post.author: Kristus
post.body:
Lumpengnom wrote:
I had to cut the branches into several smaller ase files because otherwise doom would simply hang.


That doesn't really make any sense. :S

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body:
Kristus wrote:
Lumpengnom wrote:
I had to cut the branches into several smaller ase files because otherwise doom would simply hang.


That doesn't really make any sense. :S


I don´t know either because i´m sure that i´ve imported larger files with more polys and it worked. Anyway, i had to cut the branches into 4 different ase files.
If i did not, the following would happen: I exported the ase, imported the ase and everything worked. Then i dmaped and this worked, too. When i then started the map doom would hang.

<edit>the branches are at 40.000 polys.</edit>

post.author: Kristus
post.body:
Intresting..

Anyway, I'm questioning the usefulness of the tool. Since it's so liberal in it's usage of polies, it's probably more work to optimize the model than it would be to make it manually.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
Kristus wrote:
Intresting..

Anyway, I'm questioning the usefulness of the tool. Since it's so liberal in it's usage of polies, it's probably more work to optimize the model than it would be to make it manually.

although I haven't tried it, thats what I was thinking, but we could use it for inspiration in the design of some plant models.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
I think the Ivy generator would be useful for quickly generating highpoly models which could then be projected onto alpha planes for use in game engines.
In its current state I dont really think its optimised to be used in current gen realtime engines.
its pretty new though and Im sure it will be developed into something more useful for games, those guys are pretty clever over at, http://graphics.uni-konstanz.de/publikationen/ and alot of the stuff they do is actually for realtime environment simulations, so im sure they'l develope it further.

Lumpengnom; can you show us some wires and stats of the Ivy?


Tron wrote:

Since you have all the models though you can't not give us some ingame d3 engine shots, your initial tests looked fantastic!


Ill see how I go with that tron, its just that the time I spend exporting these models to doom3 and then tweaking things in the engine could be better spent building assets, I can usually predict how a model or a texture is going to look in doom3 anyway and I just dont feel the need to put them ingame at the moment but whatever engine I use ill always post my work here.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
thats pretty amazing eh, the vines could be projected to alpha planes but I havent found a way to project alpha planes themselves like for the leaves.
Is it modifiable at all? can you replace the single leaf with a cluster of leaves and then run the program at lesser iterations?

post.author: Kristus
post.body: yeah, you can set levers to how many leafs and stuff you get.

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body: It might be possible to tie this to a mel script that created layers of low poly target meshes, then group the polies created by this with each plane based on proximity. You could then bake to each plane and get something similar to the shell based fur shaders.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
I've been getting some stuff in game, thought id better do it now before I end up with 50 odd assets to port to quake4, despite what I said earlier about not bothering what a silly idea that was.
Its not showing the best fps there, nothing's optimised in regards to textures and it seems to drop about 10 fps when I take a screenshot for some reason, but im not too concerned about the stats at the moment, i should be able to optimise it later if I need to, to get it running decently. Also ill be giving all the assets from my wip to the guys at the Ground Zero mod so you'll probably get hold of them fairly soon to use in your maps.

post.author: BJA
post.body:
Wow, that looks incredible ingame
Texturing, modeling and geometry are really great.
How exactly did you do that ? you baked the diffuse texture on the highpoly models (without making a low poly version)?

post.author: Rayne
post.body: That's the quality mods should feature at this time

post.author: dirk
post.body: great work!

post.author: mikebart
post.body: BJA; this is the high-poly model and it has all the diffuse information as well as the geometry for the normal map, I started by making alot of small models like the plants, bricks, cement etc... and textured them, then baked the whole lot onto the low poly model in 3dsmax using the projection modifier. The only disadvantage to this aproach IMO is that theres not alot of tiling going on so these models are quite hungry on texture memory, but still, I like the effect.

post.author: dirk
post.body: realy nice, have you tryd the paralax shader, the result is convincing in all directions (displaying, performance ...)

post.author: Black Dog
post.body:
That looks very nice. It's a bit strange that the arches continue past their keystone without any support, and the lighting is also too strong as you can see detail being blown out on your lighter surfaces. Still, damn cool.

Are you just having a bit of fun here, or are there further plans?

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
thanks dirk, ill have a look at the paralax shader

I was waiting for someone to say that about the arches . The arches will be in place of the arches on the face of the building itself, so there will be a large hole with bricks and rubble piled up underneath, Ill do a few tests with different lighting soon, I just want to try and get the model complete first.
Im just playing around really, experimenting with max.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: very nice markbart. did you model by hand the curtains or use some automated tool to create the folds, waves? in blender we can attach wave modifiers to meshes which do a lot of the hard work for us, we just have to tweak a few parameters.

post.author: mikebart
post.body: theres a wave modifier in max too, I played around with it initialy but in the end i didnt use it, I moved all the vertexes by hand to create the folds and then subdivided the mesh

post.body: understood and thats even more impressive

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
its all low poly now, apart from the broken glass which needs a texture, im hoping it should all be under 2000 polys when its finished, its about 1700 at the moment. Ive also changed a few things with the bottom story I removed the tiles and widened the windows.

these are max renders just two omni lights, one with area shadows.

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body: lookin good! you might want to put a slot in the window pane where the glass sits. The parts with red brick showing through seems a little incongruous- the exposed bricks are too clean, yet also have a lot of depth in the grout compared to the other parts that're super smooth like glazed concrete. The orange in the brick and green in the leaves seem really saturated compared to the rest of the colors. The purplish cracking window pane is awesome.

post.body:
yeah so am I, they're all 2048 at the moment mainly just for the max renders I seriously need to upgrade my PC though.
I figure that by the time I finish this project we'll all be driving around in hover cars and the average PC will be well above the requirements to run my map .

If etqw comes out with a UI shader program then I might stick with it but I know my way around UnrealEd enough to be able to put assets in there and I think its alot more user freindly than Doom3 and its selling licences like hot cakes.

post.author: Kristus
post.body:
I just made a quick test of it today. But the generator is not exactly very economic in it's use of polies. a small scrub, ended up at 4000 polies.

after I removed a bunch of the excessive branches, I got it down to about half though.

Since it's exporting to obj files, it's not harder to get it into Doom3, than it is to make any custom models for Doom3 really. (atleast it isn't for me, since I often use the export to obj function in Radiant to make the custom models seam up with the maps I've built)

But since you're using Blender (right) I don't know how well it support the .obj format.

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body:
I just did a test and it works but it´s a bit tricky.
I import the obj to Max, separate the leaves from the branches and export to ase.
The leaves work fine but i´m having trouble with the branches. I had to cut the branches into several smaller ase files because otherwise doom would simply hang.
Here´s a test image.

<edit>Blender handles obj fine.</edit>

I had to cut the branches into several smaller ase files because otherwise doom would simply hang.


That doesn't really make any sense. :S

If i did not, the following would happen: I exported the ase, imported the ase and everything worked. Then i dmaped and this worked, too. When i then started the map doom would hang.

post.author: mikebart
post.body: BJA; this is the high-poly model and it has all the diffuse information as well as the geometry for the normal map, I started by making alot of small models like the plants, bricks, cement etc... and textured them, then baked the whole lot onto the low poly model in 3dsmax using the projection modifier. The only disadvantage to this aproach IMO is that theres not alot of tiling going on so these models are quite hungry on texture memory, but still, I like the effect.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
I think the Ivy generator would be useful for quickly generating highpoly models which could then be projected onto alpha planes for use in game engines.
In its current state I dont really think its optimised to be used in current gen realtime engines.
its pretty new though and Im sure it will be developed into something more useful for games, those guys are pretty clever over at, http://graphics.uni-konstanz.de/publikationen/ and alot of the stuff they do is actually for realtime environment simulations, so im sure they'l develope it further.

Since you have all the models though you can't not give us some ingame d3 engine shots, your initial tests looked fantastic!


Ill see how I go with that tron, its just that the time I spend exporting these models to doom3 and then tweaking things in the engine could be better spent building assets, I can usually predict how a model or a texture is going to look in doom3 anyway and I just dont feel the need to put them ingame at the moment but whatever engine I use ill always post my work here.

post.author: Manc
post.body:
ViPr wrote:
why have you put only diffuse textures on the high poly models?

Why would you need anything else? Are you expecting him to use glossmaps or something? The objects are built up from smaller bits so other than maybe a subtle bump/height map there's no point in using anything else. It won't translate directly to doom3. He could add a sublte bump/height map or spec to the low poly for the purposes of using it in game but it almost really doesn't need it.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: Kiltron, I like the moon lit coloring in your concept for mikebart

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
thanks for the feedback guys ,
@vipr, at the moment there's only the diffuse, specular(very subtle) and normal map's, i might paint in a height map, but that would be done in photoshop, what other textures (to be baked from max) did you have in mind?

@Kiltron; thanks for the awesome concept, you hit the nail on the head, my plan was to create a city/suburbian scene wich has fallen to the effects of global warming, everywhere where you see a concentration of the creeper plants on the building, will have alpha channeled creeper plants clustered/hanging from them.
I thought by baking them into the texture itself it would help the alpha-channels flow into the solid texture's, ive done a few tests and it looks pretty convincing.
I found the smaller leaves were easier to handle as a normal map because they're only a few pixels each, so its easier to see the direction the leaf/normals are facing, but I love the ivy you've composited on the concept, it would be great to get it looking like that in game.

post.author: modern
post.body:
I was looking at a Crysis screenshot yesturday:

http://www.crytek.com/screenshots/index ... ompare.jpg

The only thing I would say about the crysis shot is that I can see repition. Alot of the foliage and grass is a uniform colour, and could benefit from just alittle more colour variation just like you have established in the brick work of your screenshot (a shader that reduces saturation and contrast with distance wouldn't go amiss aswell).

A while ago I was looking at a piece of my own work and I noticed how my ivy was one shade of green and my tree leaves were a different shade of green. I found the difference quite jaring, and I can see a similar thing going on here.

Its just a suggestion but you could try making the warm yellowy green of the grass and tree leaves alittle closer to the cool bluish green of the creeping vine.

Then maybe you could introduce some of the bluish green colour into the grass and tree leaves, and put some of the warm yellowish green into the creeping vine.

I very much like the contrast of the blue flowers against the overall orangyness of the scene. Maybe you could make more of that relationship? Some blue flower models? You could try a very subtle desaturated, dark, cool blue ambient light under the arches.

Inspirational stuff.

edit: I think I can see a similar mix of warm yellowy green and cool bluish geen in the tree in this shot:-

post.author: Tron
post.body: I'm curious, how much reuse of models is there in this level between different areas? Because if you are going for lots of unique models and really want to show off you could do some basic radiosity lighting in max and bake that into glowmaps. If models are being reused lots it obviously wouldn't work, but if you're intending to make this a smallish test area it could look very very nice.

post.author: Dj Dooms Day
post.body:
Really? You can do that? I didn't think there was any way to get radiosity into D3. Thats really neat.

Mikebart - Got any updates for us on this?

post.author: Tron
post.body:
Dj Dooms Day wrote:
Really? You can do that? I didn't think there was any way to get radiosity into D3. Thats really neat.

Mikebart - Got any updates for us on this?


Well it's not exactly an idea solution, but if you have an area which has unique texturing like this you can bake some lighting into the textures. If you're going to be using realtime lights as well (as you would want when you're going to have objects like players which need to interact with the world) you don't want to go over the top with the pre-computer lighting though, just a bit of a subtle effect to fill out those dark spots.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
The building project's been put on hold for a while and I've been contributing my time to the dark mod for the last month or so, but ill get back into it eventually.

Some of the models are duplicates, like some of the loose bricks and things and one half of each of the broken arches are the same model, the columns are duplicates too.

Thats a great idea, If it were to be used for more distant structures you could build a low poly model around a group of low poly models like for example the damaged building model and project them to one large glow map, the same can be done for diffuse, spec and normals. I think you could acheive quite a realistic scene.

post.author: Kristus
post.body:
I just made a quick test of it today. But the generator is not exactly very economic in it's use of polies. a small scrub, ended up at 4000 polies.

after I removed a bunch of the excessive branches, I got it down to about half though.

Since it's exporting to obj files, it's not harder to get it into Doom3, than it is to make any custom models for Doom3 really. (atleast it isn't for me, since I often use the export to obj function in Radiant to make the custom models seam up with the maps I've built)

But since you're using Blender (right) I don't know how well it support the .obj format.

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body:
I just did a test and it works but it´s a bit tricky.
I import the obj to Max, separate the leaves from the branches and export to ase.
The leaves work fine but i´m having trouble with the branches. I had to cut the branches into several smaller ase files because otherwise doom would simply hang.
Here´s a test image.

<edit>Blender handles obj fine.</edit>

post.author: Kristus
post.body:
Lumpengnom wrote:
I had to cut the branches into several smaller ase files because otherwise doom would simply hang.


That doesn't really make any sense. :S

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body:
Kristus wrote:
Lumpengnom wrote:
I had to cut the branches into several smaller ase files because otherwise doom would simply hang.


That doesn't really make any sense. :S


I don´t know either because i´m sure that i´ve imported larger files with more polys and it worked. Anyway, i had to cut the branches into 4 different ase files.
If i did not, the following would happen: I exported the ase, imported the ase and everything worked. Then i dmaped and this worked, too. When i then started the map doom would hang.

<edit>the branches are at 40.000 polys.</edit>

post.author: Kristus
post.body:
Intresting..

Anyway, I'm questioning the usefulness of the tool. Since it's so liberal in it's usage of polies, it's probably more work to optimize the model than it would be to make it manually.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
Kristus wrote:
Intresting..

Anyway, I'm questioning the usefulness of the tool. Since it's so liberal in it's usage of polies, it's probably more work to optimize the model than it would be to make it manually.

although I haven't tried it, thats what I was thinking, but we could use it for inspiration in the design of some plant models.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
I think the Ivy generator would be useful for quickly generating highpoly models which could then be projected onto alpha planes for use in game engines.
In its current state I dont really think its optimised to be used in current gen realtime engines.
its pretty new though and Im sure it will be developed into something more useful for games, those guys are pretty clever over at, http://graphics.uni-konstanz.de/publikationen/ and alot of the stuff they do is actually for realtime environment simulations, so im sure they'l develope it further.

Lumpengnom; can you show us some wires and stats of the Ivy?


Tron wrote:

Since you have all the models though you can't not give us some ingame d3 engine shots, your initial tests looked fantastic!


Ill see how I go with that tron, its just that the time I spend exporting these models to doom3 and then tweaking things in the engine could be better spent building assets, I can usually predict how a model or a texture is going to look in doom3 anyway and I just dont feel the need to put them ingame at the moment but whatever engine I use ill always post my work here.

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body:
mikebart wrote:
Lumpengnom; can you show us some wires and stats of the Ivy?


Actually not from that example because i no longer have the file but it was around 70K Polys.

Here´s a wire of another one i generated:

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
thats pretty amazing eh, the vines could be projected to alpha planes but I havent found a way to project alpha planes themselves like for the leaves.
Is it modifiable at all? can you replace the single leaf with a cluster of leaves and then run the program at lesser iterations?

post.author: Kristus
post.body: yeah, you can set levers to how many leafs and stuff you get.

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body: It might be possible to tie this to a mel script that created layers of low poly target meshes, then group the polies created by this with each plane based on proximity. You could then bake to each plane and get something similar to the shell based fur shaders.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
I've been getting some stuff in game, thought id better do it now before I end up with 50 odd assets to port to quake4, despite what I said earlier about not bothering what a silly idea that was.
Its not showing the best fps there, nothing's optimised in regards to textures and it seems to drop about 10 fps when I take a screenshot for some reason, but im not too concerned about the stats at the moment, i should be able to optimise it later if I need to, to get it running decently. Also ill be giving all the assets from my wip to the guys at the Ground Zero mod so you'll probably get hold of them fairly soon to use in your maps.

post.author: g0th
post.body: Great stuff Mikebart

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body: That´s really amazing work. Many games (not just mods but also commercial games) fail to get the colors and contrasts right which makes games look either bland (FEAR) or too bright colored (Unreal). These colors and contrasts you´ve got in your work are next to perfect, imo.

post.author: Hostyle
post.body: Are these assets for a future playable level or just your 3d playground? If its just a graphics playground you should stick to 3dsmax and dont worry about speed or smth.

post.author: Tron
post.body: This is looking good.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
Lumpengnom wrote:
That´s really amazing work. Many games (not just mods but also commercial games) fail to get the colors and contrasts right which makes games look either bland (FEAR) or too bright colored (Unreal). These colors and contrasts you´ve got in your work are next to perfect, imo.


Thanks, I really payed more attention to the colour's in this one after I felt my last building was a failure in regard to colour theory.
The only thing that looks a bit out in those images to me is the grass, but ill put in some pavement and girth in there instead.



Hostyle wrote:
Are these assets for a future playable level or just your 3d playground? If its just a graphics playground you should stick to 3dsmax and dont worry about speed or smth.


Im really just putting it in the game so that its ready for the ground zero mod, it'll have to be heavily modified to work I think, especially if we make it destructible.
I was just going to keep it in max initially, just because it looks better, with alpha shadows and soft shadows and all that but I was advised to put it ingame for good reason;
If I went for a job they'd want to see that I can work within the constraints of a game engine aswell as a 3d renderer.

post.author: Bo$bevok
post.body: you're gonna make it all destructable?!?! .....

we're only really just been talking about it at the moment, discussing the best way to go about it, the only unique texture on the building is the arch which includes the ornament aswell, all the rest could be sized down to be quite small, but like i said it will need to be heavily modified to work.

@hexum; thx

post.author: mikebart

heres some more shots of the new building, im gradualy converting it from high to low poly.

hi poly = 39891 tris, low poly = 1454. (thats just the ornament btw.)

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: very nice markbart. did you model by hand the curtains or use some automated tool to create the folds, waves? in blender we can attach wave modifiers to meshes which do a lot of the hard work for us, we just have to tweak a few parameters.

post.author: mikebart
post.body: theres a wave modifier in max too, I played around with it initialy but in the end i didnt use it, I moved all the vertexes by hand to create the folds and then subdivided the mesh

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: understood and thats even more impressive

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
its all low poly now, apart from the broken glass which needs a texture, im hoping it should all be under 2000 polys when its finished, its about 1700 at the moment. Ive also changed a few things with the bottom story I removed the tiles and widened the windows.

these are max renders just two omni lights, one with area shadows.

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body: lookin good! you might want to put a slot in the window pane where the glass sits. The parts with red brick showing through seems a little incongruous- the exposed bricks are too clean, yet also have a lot of depth in the grout compared to the other parts that're super smooth like glazed concrete. The orange in the brick and green in the leaves seem really saturated compared to the rest of the colors. The purplish cracking window pane is awesome.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
thanks for the crits parsons, im glad we're doing something similar, that should benefit both our works.
cheers

post.author: Kristus
post.body: Still looking great. Please make a whole mod. :p

post.author: Bo$bevok
post.body:
keep on going man it does look awesome...

the only thing you could maybe change is that the orange bricks look so neat...

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
thanks guys,
i plan on adding grime/dirt maps to the diffuse using a blend in the doom3 shader, so ill leave the dirty details for later, for now im just concentrating on baking some base textures, ill be able to repeat the model several times and having several different grime/dirt maps should give me some good variation.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
Just a a small update, Ive added an ao pass and dirtmap to the diffuse texture of the ornament and arch.

post.author: Tron
post.body: I'm really looking forward to seeing some more ingame shots. I am terrified of how much texture memory your project is going to use though.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
yeah so am I, they're all 2048 at the moment mainly just for the max renders I seriously need to upgrade my PC though.
I figure that by the time I finish this project we'll all be driving around in hover cars and the average PC will be well above the requirements to run my map .

I think rather than put it in doom3 though, I might just keep working on it in max and then decide on another engine later, see what comes out.
If etqw comes out with a UI shader program then I might stick with it but I know my way around UnrealEd enough to be able to put assets in there and I think its alot more user freindly than Doom3 and its selling licences like hot cakes.

post.author: Rayne
post.body: That's the quality mods should feature at this time

post.author: dirk
post.body: great work!

post.author: mikebart
post.body: BJA; this is the high-poly model and it has all the diffuse information as well as the geometry for the normal map, I started by making alot of small models like the plants, bricks, cement etc... and textured them, then baked the whole lot onto the low poly model in 3dsmax using the projection modifier. The only disadvantage to this aproach IMO is that theres not alot of tiling going on so these models are quite hungry on texture memory, but still, I like the effect.

post.author: dirk
post.body: realy nice, have you tryd the paralax shader, the result is convincing in all directions (displaying, performance ...)

post.author: Black Dog
post.body:
That looks very nice. It's a bit strange that the arches continue past their keystone without any support, and the lighting is also too strong as you can see detail being blown out on your lighter surfaces. Still, damn cool.

Are you just having a bit of fun here, or are there further plans?

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
thanks dirk, ill have a look at the paralax shader

I was waiting for someone to say that about the arches . The arches will be in place of the arches on the face of the building itself, so there will be a large hole with bricks and rubble piled up underneath, Ill do a few tests with different lighting soon, I just want to try and get the model complete first.
Im just playing around really, experimenting with max.

post.author: Jack Rammsdell
post.body: wow that looks really good ingame

post.author: modern
post.body: Yeah, thats worked out real nice. I like the distress in the brick work. How about adding some moodier lighting?

post.author: BJA
post.body:
Wow, that looks incredible ingame
Texturing, modeling and geometry are really great.
How exactly did you do that ? you baked the diffuse texture on the highpoly models (without making a low poly version)?

post.author: Rayne
post.body: That's the quality mods should feature at this time

post.author: dirk
post.body: great work!

post.author: mikebart
post.body: BJA; this is the high-poly model and it has all the diffuse information as well as the geometry for the normal map, I started by making alot of small models like the plants, bricks, cement etc... and textured them, then baked the whole lot onto the low poly model in 3dsmax using the projection modifier. The only disadvantage to this aproach IMO is that theres not alot of tiling going on so these models are quite hungry on texture memory, but still, I like the effect.

post.author: dirk
post.body: realy nice, have you tryd the paralax shader, the result is convincing in all directions (displaying, performance ...)

post.author: Black Dog
post.body:
That looks very nice. It's a bit strange that the arches continue past their keystone without any support, and the lighting is also too strong as you can see detail being blown out on your lighter surfaces. Still, damn cool.

Are you just having a bit of fun here, or are there further plans?

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
thanks dirk, ill have a look at the paralax shader

I was waiting for someone to say that about the arches . The arches will be in place of the arches on the face of the building itself, so there will be a large hole with bricks and rubble piled up underneath, Ill do a few tests with different lighting soon, I just want to try and get the model complete first.
Im just playing around really, experimenting with max.

post.author: heXum
post.body: Eat your heart out, Gears of War!

post.body:

post.author: mikebart
post.body: BJA; this is the high-poly model and it has all the diffuse information as well as the geometry for the normal map, I started by making alot of small models like the plants, bricks, cement etc... and textured them, then baked the whole lot onto the low poly model in 3dsmax using the projection modifier. The only disadvantage to this aproach IMO is that theres not alot of tiling going on so these models are quite hungry on texture memory, but still, I like the effect.

post.author: dirk
post.body: realy nice, have you tryd the paralax shader, the result is convincing in all directions (displaying, performance ...)

post.author: Black Dog
post.body:
That looks very nice. It's a bit strange that the arches continue past their keystone without any support, and the lighting is also too strong as you can see detail being blown out on your lighter surfaces. Still, damn cool.

Are you just having a bit of fun here, or are there further plans?

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
thanks dirk, ill have a look at the paralax shader

I was waiting for someone to say that about the arches . The arches will be in place of the arches on the face of the building itself, so there will be a large hole with bricks and rubble piled up underneath, Ill do a few tests with different lighting soon, I just want to try and get the model complete first.
Im just playing around really, experimenting with max.

post.author: Jack Rammsdell
post.body: wow that looks really good ingame

post.body: Yeah, thats worked out real nice. I like the distress in the brick work. How about adding some moodier lighting?

post.author: BJA
post.body:
Wow, that looks incredible ingame
Texturing, modeling and geometry are really great.
How exactly did you do that ? you baked the diffuse texture on the highpoly models (without making a low poly version)?

post.author: Rayne
post.body: That's the quality mods should feature at this time

post.author: dirk
post.body: great work!

post.author: mikebart
post.body: BJA; this is the high-poly model and it has all the diffuse information as well as the geometry for the normal map, I started by making alot of small models like the plants, bricks, cement etc... and textured them, then baked the whole lot onto the low poly model in 3dsmax using the projection modifier. The only disadvantage to this aproach IMO is that theres not alot of tiling going on so these models are quite hungry on texture memory, but still, I like the effect.

post.author: dirk
post.body: realy nice, have you tryd the paralax shader, the result is convincing in all directions (displaying, performance ...)

post.author: Black Dog
post.body:
That looks very nice. It's a bit strange that the arches continue past their keystone without any support, and the lighting is also too strong as you can see detail being blown out on your lighter surfaces. Still, damn cool.

Are you just having a bit of fun here, or are there further plans?

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
thanks dirk, ill have a look at the paralax shader

I was waiting for someone to say that about the arches . The arches will be in place of the arches on the face of the building itself, so there will be a large hole with bricks and rubble piled up underneath, Ill do a few tests with different lighting soon, I just want to try and get the model complete first.
Im just playing around really, experimenting with max.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
heres some more shots of the new building, im gradualy converting it from high to low poly.

hi poly = 39891 tris, low poly = 1454. (thats just the ornament btw.)

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: very nice markbart. did you model by hand the curtains or use some automated tool to create the folds, waves? in blender we can attach wave modifiers to meshes which do a lot of the hard work for us, we just have to tweak a few parameters.

post.author: mikebart
post.body: theres a wave modifier in max too, I played around with it initialy but in the end i didnt use it, I moved all the vertexes by hand to create the folds and then subdivided the mesh

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: understood and thats even more impressive

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
its all low poly now, apart from the broken glass which needs a texture, im hoping it should all be under 2000 polys when its finished, its about 1700 at the moment. Ive also changed a few things with the bottom story I removed the tiles and widened the windows.

these are max renders just two omni lights, one with area shadows.

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body: lookin good! you might want to put a slot in the window pane where the glass sits. The parts with red brick showing through seems a little incongruous- the exposed bricks are too clean, yet also have a lot of depth in the grout compared to the other parts that're super smooth like glazed concrete. The orange in the brick and green in the leaves seem really saturated compared to the rest of the colors. The purplish cracking window pane is awesome.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
thanks for the crits parsons, im glad we're doing something similar, that should benefit both our works.
cheers

post.author: Kristus
post.body: Still looking great. Please make a whole mod. :p

post.author: Bo$bevok
post.body:
keep on going man it does look awesome...

the only thing you could maybe change is that the orange bricks look so neat...

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
thanks guys,
i plan on adding grime/dirt maps to the diffuse using a blend in the doom3 shader, so ill leave the dirty details for later, for now im just concentrating on baking some base textures, ill be able to repeat the model several times and having several different grime/dirt maps should give me some good variation.

The orange in the brick and green in the leaves seem really saturated compared to the rest of the colors. The purplish cracking window pane is awesome.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
thanks for the crits parsons, im glad we're doing something similar, that should benefit both our works.
cheers

post.author: mikebart

heres some more shots of the new building, im gradualy converting it from high to low poly.

hi poly = 39891 tris, low poly = 1454. (thats just the ornament btw.)

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: very nice markbart. did you model by hand the curtains or use some automated tool to create the folds, waves? in blender we can attach wave modifiers to meshes which do a lot of the hard work for us, we just have to tweak a few parameters.

post.author: mikebart
post.body: theres a wave modifier in max too, I played around with it initialy but in the end i didnt use it, I moved all the vertexes by hand to create the folds and then subdivided the mesh

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: understood and thats even more impressive

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
its all low poly now, apart from the broken glass which needs a texture, im hoping it should all be under 2000 polys when its finished, its about 1700 at the moment. Ive also changed a few things with the bottom story I removed the tiles and widened the windows.

these are max renders just two omni lights, one with area shadows.

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body: lookin good! you might want to put a slot in the window pane where the glass sits. The parts with red brick showing through seems a little incongruous- the exposed bricks are too clean, yet also have a lot of depth in the grout compared to the other parts that're super smooth like glazed concrete. The orange in the brick and green in the leaves seem really saturated compared to the rest of the colors. The purplish cracking window pane is awesome.

cheers

post.date: Posted: Sat Mar 24, 2007 2:19 pm Post subject:
post.author: Tron
post.body: I'm really looking forward to seeing some more ingame shots. I am terrified of how much texture memory your project is going to use though.

post.date: Posted: Sat Mar 24, 2007 2:34 pm Post subject:
post.author: mikebart
post.body:
yeah so am I, they're all 2048 at the moment mainly just for the max renders I seriously need to upgrade my PC though.
I figure that by the time I finish this project we'll all be driving around in hover cars and the average PC will be well above the requirements to run my map .

I think rather than put it in doom3 though, I might just keep working on it in max and then decide on another engine later, see what comes out.
If etqw comes out with a UI shader program then I might stick with it but I know my way around UnrealEd enough to be able to put assets in there and I think its alot more user freindly than Doom3 and its selling licences like hot cakes.
_________________
Tutorial; Baking Multiple Maps in 3dsmax8.

post.author: Tron
post.body: I'm really looking forward to seeing some more ingame shots. I am terrified of how much texture memory your project is going to use though.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
yeah so am I, they're all 2048 at the moment mainly just for the max renders I seriously need to upgrade my PC though.
I figure that by the time I finish this project we'll all be driving around in hover cars and the average PC will be well above the requirements to run my map .

I think rather than put it in doom3 though, I might just keep working on it in max and then decide on another engine later, see what comes out.
If etqw comes out with a UI shader program then I might stick with it but I know my way around UnrealEd enough to be able to put assets in there and I think its alot more user freindly than Doom3 and its selling licences like hot cakes.

post.author: Kristus
post.body:
I just made a quick test of it today. But the generator is not exactly very economic in it's use of polies. a small scrub, ended up at 4000 polies.

after I removed a bunch of the excessive branches, I got it down to about half though.

Since it's exporting to obj files, it's not harder to get it into Doom3, than it is to make any custom models for Doom3 really. (atleast it isn't for me, since I often use the export to obj function in Radiant to make the custom models seam up with the maps I've built)

But since you're using Blender (right) I don't know how well it support the .obj format.

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body:
I just did a test and it works but it´s a bit tricky.
I import the obj to Max, separate the leaves from the branches and export to ase.
The leaves work fine but i´m having trouble with the branches. I had to cut the branches into several smaller ase files because otherwise doom would simply hang.
Here´s a test image.

<edit>Blender handles obj fine.</edit>

post.author: Kristus
post.body:
Lumpengnom wrote:
I had to cut the branches into several smaller ase files because otherwise doom would simply hang.


That doesn't really make any sense. :S

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body:
Kristus wrote:
Lumpengnom wrote:
I had to cut the branches into several smaller ase files because otherwise doom would simply hang.


That doesn't really make any sense. :S


I don´t know either because i´m sure that i´ve imported larger files with more polys and it worked. Anyway, i had to cut the branches into 4 different ase files.
If i did not, the following would happen: I exported the ase, imported the ase and everything worked. Then i dmaped and this worked, too. When i then started the map doom would hang.

<edit>the branches are at 40.000 polys.</edit>

Since it's exporting to obj files, it's not harder to get it into Doom3, than it is to make any custom models for Doom3 really. (atleast it isn't for me, since I often use the export to obj function in Radiant to make the custom models seam up with the maps I've built)

If etqw comes out with a UI shader program then I might stick with it but I know my way around UnrealEd enough to be able to put assets in there and I think its alot more user freindly than Doom3 and its selling licences like hot cakes.


Since you have all the models though you can't not give us some ingame d3 engine shots, your initial tests looked fantastic!

I just made a quick test of it today. But the generator is not exactly very economic in it's use of polies. a small scrub, ended up at 4000 polies.

after I removed a bunch of the excessive branches, I got it down to about half though.

Since it's exporting to obj files, it's not harder to get it into Doom3, than it is to make any custom models for Doom3 really. (atleast it isn't for me, since I often use the export to obj function in Radiant to make the custom models seam up with the maps I've built)

But since you're using Blender (right) I don't know how well it support the .obj format.

I just did a test and it works but it´s a bit tricky.
I import the obj to Max, separate the leaves from the branches and export to ase.
The leaves work fine but i´m having trouble with the branches. I had to cut the branches into several smaller ase files because otherwise doom would simply hang.

post.author: Kristus
post.body:
I just made a quick test of it today. But the generator is not exactly very economic in it's use of polies. a small scrub, ended up at 4000 polies.

after I removed a bunch of the excessive branches, I got it down to about half though.

Since it's exporting to obj files, it's not harder to get it into Doom3, than it is to make any custom models for Doom3 really. (atleast it isn't for me, since I often use the export to obj function in Radiant to make the custom models seam up with the maps I've built)

But since you're using Blender (right) I don't know how well it support the .obj format.

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body:
I just did a test and it works but it´s a bit tricky.
I import the obj to Max, separate the leaves from the branches and export to ase.
The leaves work fine but i´m having trouble with the branches. I had to cut the branches into several smaller ase files because otherwise doom would simply hang.
Here´s a test image.

<edit>Blender handles obj fine.</edit>

post.author: Kristus
post.body:
Lumpengnom wrote:
I had to cut the branches into several smaller ase files because otherwise doom would simply hang.


That doesn't really make any sense. :S

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body:
Kristus wrote:
Lumpengnom wrote:
I had to cut the branches into several smaller ase files because otherwise doom would simply hang.


That doesn't really make any sense. :S


I don´t know either because i´m sure that i´ve imported larger files with more polys and it worked. Anyway, i had to cut the branches into 4 different ase files.
If i did not, the following would happen: I exported the ase, imported the ase and everything worked. Then i dmaped and this worked, too. When i then started the map doom would hang.

<edit>the branches are at 40.000 polys.</edit>

If etqw comes out with a UI shader program then I might stick with it but I know my way around UnrealEd enough to be able to put assets in there and I think its alot more user freindly than Doom3 and its selling licences like hot cakes.

I just made a quick test of it today. But the generator is not exactly very economic in it's use of polies. a small scrub, ended up at 4000 polies.

after I removed a bunch of the excessive branches, I got it down to about half though.

Since it's exporting to obj files, it's not harder to get it into Doom3, than it is to make any custom models for Doom3 really. (atleast it isn't for me, since I often use the export to obj function in Radiant to make the custom models seam up with the maps I've built)

But since you're using Blender (right) I don't know how well it support the .obj format.

I just made a quick test of it today. But the generator is not exactly very economic in it's use of polies. a small scrub, ended up at 4000 polies.

after I removed a bunch of the excessive branches, I got it down to about half though.

Since it's exporting to obj files, it's not harder to get it into Doom3, than it is to make any custom models for Doom3 really. (atleast it isn't for me, since I often use the export to obj function in Radiant to make the custom models seam up with the maps I've built)

But since you're using Blender (right) I don't know how well it support the .obj format.

I just did a test and it works but it´s a bit tricky.
I import the obj to Max, separate the leaves from the branches and export to ase.
The leaves work fine but i´m having trouble with the branches. I had to cut the branches into several smaller ase files because otherwise doom would simply hang.
Here´s a test image.

<edit>Blender handles obj fine.</edit>

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
Kristus wrote:
Intresting..

Anyway, I'm questioning the usefulness of the tool. Since it's so liberal in it's usage of polies, it's probably more work to optimize the model than it would be to make it manually.

although I haven't tried it, thats what I was thinking, but we could use it for inspiration in the design of some plant models.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
I think the Ivy generator would be useful for quickly generating highpoly models which could then be projected onto alpha planes for use in game engines.
In its current state I dont really think its optimised to be used in current gen realtime engines.
its pretty new though and Im sure it will be developed into something more useful for games, those guys are pretty clever over at, http://graphics.uni-konstanz.de/publikationen/ and alot of the stuff they do is actually for realtime environment simulations, so im sure they'l develope it further.

Lumpengnom; can you show us some wires and stats of the Ivy?


Tron wrote:

Since you have all the models though you can't not give us some ingame d3 engine shots, your initial tests looked fantastic!


Ill see how I go with that tron, its just that the time I spend exporting these models to doom3 and then tweaking things in the engine could be better spent building assets, I can usually predict how a model or a texture is going to look in doom3 anyway and I just dont feel the need to put them ingame at the moment but whatever engine I use ill always post my work here.

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body:
mikebart wrote:
Lumpengnom; can you show us some wires and stats of the Ivy?


Actually not from that example because i no longer have the file but it was around 70K Polys.

Here´s a wire of another one i generated:

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
thats pretty amazing eh, the vines could be projected to alpha planes but I havent found a way to project alpha planes themselves like for the leaves.
Is it modifiable at all? can you replace the single leaf with a cluster of leaves and then run the program at lesser iterations?

post.author: Kristus
post.body: yeah, you can set levers to how many leafs and stuff you get.

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body: It might be possible to tie this to a mel script that created layers of low poly target meshes, then group the polies created by this with each plane based on proximity. You could then bake to each plane and get something similar to the shell based fur shaders.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
I've been getting some stuff in game, thought id better do it now before I end up with 50 odd assets to port to quake4, despite what I said earlier about not bothering what a silly idea that was.
Its not showing the best fps there, nothing's optimised in regards to textures and it seems to drop about 10 fps when I take a screenshot for some reason, but im not too concerned about the stats at the moment, i should be able to optimise it later if I need to, to get it running decently. Also ill be giving all the assets from my wip to the guys at the Ground Zero mod so you'll probably get hold of them fairly soon to use in your maps.

post.author: g0th
post.body: Great stuff Mikebart

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body: That´s really amazing work. Many games (not just mods but also commercial games) fail to get the colors and contrasts right which makes games look either bland (FEAR) or too bright colored (Unreal). These colors and contrasts you´ve got in your work are next to perfect, imo.

post.author: Hostyle
post.body: Are these assets for a future playable level or just your 3d playground? If its just a graphics playground you should stick to 3dsmax and dont worry about speed or smth.

post.author: Tron
post.body: This is looking good.

post.author: m!chi:be
post.body:

Anyway, I'm questioning the usefulness of the tool. Since it's so liberal in it's usage of polies, it's probably more work to optimize the model than it would be to make it manually.


Its not made for Realtime Games or such. Its for CG guys. and theres no problem wit hthe polycount.

post.author: Bo$bevok
post.body: nothing short of breathtaking...

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
Lumpengnom wrote:
That´s really amazing work. Many games (not just mods but also commercial games) fail to get the colors and contrasts right which makes games look either bland (FEAR) or too bright colored (Unreal). These colors and contrasts you´ve got in your work are next to perfect, imo.


Thanks, I really payed more attention to the colour's in this one after I felt my last building was a failure in regard to colour theory.
The only thing that looks a bit out in those images to me is the grass, but ill put in some pavement and girth in there instead.



Hostyle wrote:
Are these assets for a future playable level or just your 3d playground? If its just a graphics playground you should stick to 3dsmax and dont worry about speed or smth.


Im really just putting it in the game so that its ready for the ground zero mod, it'll have to be heavily modified to work I think, especially if we make it destructible.
I was just going to keep it in max initially, just because it looks better, with alpha shadows and soft shadows and all that but I was advised to put it ingame for good reason;
If I went for a job they'd want to see that I can work within the constraints of a game engine aswell as a 3d renderer.

post.author: Bo$bevok
post.body: you're gonna make it all destructable?!?! .....

post.body: I don't think I've chimed in and said how impressive that stuff is. Good work!

post.body:
we're only really just been talking about it at the moment, discussing the best way to go about it, the only unique texture on the building is the arch which includes the ornament aswell, all the rest could be sized down to be quite small, but like i said it will need to be heavily modified to work.

@hexum; thx

<!--
/*
  The original subSilver Theme for phpBB version 2+

  /web/20070509181516/http://www.subblue.com

  NOTE: These CSS definitions are stored within the main page body so that you can use the phpBB2
  theme administration centre. When you have finalised your style you could cut the final CSS code
  and place it in an external file, deleting this section to save bandwidth.
*/

/* General page style. The scroll bar colours only visible in IE5.5+ */
body {
	background-color: #E5E5E5;
	scrollbar-face-color: #DEE3E7;
	scrollbar-highlight-color: #FFFFFF;
	scrollbar-shadow-color: #DEE3E7;
	scrollbar-3dlight-color: #D1D7DC;
	scrollbar-arrow-color:  #006699;
	scrollbar-track-color: #EFEFEF;
	scrollbar-darkshadow-color: #98AAB1;
}

/* General font families for common tags */
font,th,td,p { font-family: Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif }
a:link,a:active,a:visited { color : #006699; }
a:hover		{ text-decoration: underline; color : #DD6900; }
hr	{ height: 0px; border: solid #D1D7DC 0px; border-top-width: 1px;}

/* This is the border line & background colour round the entire page */
.bodyline	{ background-color: #FFFFFF; border: 1px #98AAB1 solid; }

/* This is the outline round the main forum tables */
.forumline	{ background-color: #FFFFFF; border: 2px #006699 solid; }

/* Main table cell colours and backgrounds */
td.row1	{ background-color: #EFEFEF; }
td.row2	{ background-color: #DEE3E7; }
td.row3	{ background-color: #D1D7DC; }

/*
  This is for the table cell above the Topics, Post & Last posts on the index.php page
  By default this is the fading out gradiated silver background.
  However, you could replace this with a bitmap specific for each forum
*/
td.rowpic {
		background-color: #FFFFFF;
		background-image: url(https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/cellpic2.jpg);
		background-repeat: repeat-y;
}

/* Header cells - the blue and silver gradient backgrounds */
th	{
	color: #FFA34F; font-size: 11px; font-weight : bold;
	background-color: #006699; height: 25px;
	background-image: url(https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/cellpic3.gif);
}

td.cat,td.catHead,td.catSides,td.catLeft,td.catRight,td.catBottom {
			background-image: url(https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/cellpic1.gif);
			background-color:#D1D7DC; border: #FFFFFF; border-style: solid; height: 28px;
}

/*
  Setting additional nice inner borders for the main table cells.
  The names indicate which sides the border will be on.
  Don't worry if you don't understand this, just ignore it :-)
*/
td.cat,td.catHead,td.catBottom {
	height: 29px;
	border-width: 0px 0px 0px 0px;
}
th.thHead,th.thSides,th.thTop,th.thLeft,th.thRight,th.thBottom,th.thCornerL,th.thCornerR {
	font-weight: bold; border: #FFFFFF; border-style: solid; height: 28px;
}
td.row3Right,td.spaceRow {
	background-color: #D1D7DC; border: #FFFFFF; border-style: solid;
}

th.thHead,td.catHead { font-size: 12px; border-width: 1px 1px 0px 1px; }
th.thSides,td.catSides,td.spaceRow	 { border-width: 0px 1px 0px 1px; }
th.thRight,td.catRight,td.row3Right	 { border-width: 0px 1px 0px 0px; }
th.thLeft,td.catLeft	  { border-width: 0px 0px 0px 1px; }
th.thBottom,td.catBottom  { border-width: 0px 1px 1px 1px; }
th.thTop	 { border-width: 1px 0px 0px 0px; }
th.thCornerL { border-width: 1px 0px 0px 1px; }
th.thCornerR { border-width: 1px 1px 0px 0px; }

/* The largest text used in the index page title and toptic title etc. */
.maintitle	{
	font-weight: bold; font-size: 22px; font-family: "Trebuchet MS",Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
	text-decoration: none; line-height : 120%; color : #000000;
}

/* General text */
.gen { font-size : 12px; }
.genmed { font-size : 11px; }
.gensmall { font-size : 10px; }
.gen,.genmed,.gensmall { color : #000000; }
a.gen,a.genmed,a.gensmall { color: #006699; text-decoration: none; }
a.gen:hover,a.genmed:hover,a.gensmall:hover	{ color: #DD6900; text-decoration: underline; }

/* The register, login, search etc links at the top of the page */
.mainmenu		{ font-size : 11px; color : #000000 }
a.mainmenu		{ text-decoration: none; color : #006699;  }
a.mainmenu:hover{ text-decoration: underline; color : #DD6900; }

/* Forum category titles */
.cattitle		{ font-weight: bold; font-size: 12px ; letter-spacing: 1px; color : #006699}
a.cattitle		{ text-decoration: none; color : #006699; }
a.cattitle:hover{ text-decoration: underline; }

/* Forum title: Text and link to the forums used in: index.php */
.forumlink		{ font-weight: bold; font-size: 12px; color : #006699; }
a.forumlink 	{ text-decoration: none; color : #006699; }
a.forumlink:hover{ text-decoration: underline; color : #DD6900; }

/* Used for the navigation text, (Page 1,2,3 etc) and the navigation bar when in a forum */
.nav			{ font-weight: bold; font-size: 11px; color : #000000;}
a.nav			{ text-decoration: none; color : #006699; }
a.nav:hover		{ text-decoration: underline; }

/* titles for the topics: could specify viewed link colour too */
.topictitle,h1,h2	{ font-weight: bold; font-size: 11px; color : #000000; }
a.topictitle:link   { text-decoration: none; color : #006699; }
a.topictitle:visited { text-decoration: none; color : #5493B4; }
a.topictitle:hover	{ text-decoration: underline; color : #DD6900; }

/* Name of poster in viewmsg.php and viewtopic.php and other places */
.name			{ font-size : 11px; color : #000000;}

/* Location, number of posts, post date etc */
.postdetails		{ font-size : 10px; color : #000000; }

/* The content of the posts (body of text) */
.postbody { font-size : 12px; line-height: 18px}
a.postlink:link	{ text-decoration: none; color : #006699 }
a.postlink:visited { text-decoration: none; color : #5493B4; }
a.postlink:hover { text-decoration: underline; color : #DD6900}

/* Quote & Code blocks */
.code {
	font-family: Courier, 'Courier New', sans-serif; font-size: 11px; color: #006600;
	background-color: #FAFAFA; border: #D1D7DC; border-style: solid;
	border-left-width: 1px; border-top-width: 1px; border-right-width: 1px; border-bottom-width: 1px
}

.quote {
	font-family: Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 11px; color: #444444; line-height: 125%;
	background-color: #FAFAFA; border: #D1D7DC; border-style: solid;
	border-left-width: 1px; border-top-width: 1px; border-right-width: 1px; border-bottom-width: 1px
}

/* Copyright and bottom info */
.copyright		{ font-size: 10px; font-family: Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; color: #444444; letter-spacing: -1px;}
a.copyright		{ color: #444444; text-decoration: none;}
a.copyright:hover { color: #000000; text-decoration: underline;}

/* Form elements */
input,textarea, select {
	color : #000000;
	font: normal 11px Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
	border-color : #000000;
}

/* The text input fields background colour */
input.post, textarea.post, select {
	background-color : #FFFFFF;
}

input { text-indent : 2px; }

/* The buttons used for bbCode styling in message post */
input.button {
	background-color : #EFEFEF;
	color : #000000;
	font-size: 11px; font-family: Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}

/* The main submit button option */
input.mainoption {
	background-color : #FAFAFA;
	font-weight : bold;
}

/* None-bold submit button */
input.liteoption {
	background-color : #FAFAFA;
	font-weight : normal;
}

/* This is the line in the posting page which shows the rollover
  help line. This is actually a text box, but if set to be the same
  colour as the background no one will know ;)
*/
.helpline { background-color: #DEE3E7; border-style: none; }

/* Import the fancy styles for IE only (NS4.x doesn't use the @import function) */
@import url("https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/formIE.css");
-->
]] ></style>
  </head>

<script><![CDATA[ if (window.archive_analytics) { window.archive_analytics.values['server_name']="wwwb-app3.us.archive.org";}; ]] ></script><script type="text/javascript" src="https://web.archive.org/static/js/disclaim-element.js"/><script type="text/javascript" src="https://web.archive.org/static/js/graph-calc.js"/><script type="text/javascript" src="https://web.archive.org/static/jflot/jquery.min.js"/><script type="text/javascript"><![CDATA[
//<![CDATA[
var firstDate = 820454400000;
var lastDate = 1420070399999;
var wbPrefix = "/web/";
var wbCurrentUrl = "http:\/\/doom3world.org\/phpbb2\/viewtopic.php?p=177673";

var curYear = -1;
var curMonth = -1;
var yearCount = 18;
var firstYear = 1996;
var imgWidth = 475;
var yearImgWidth = 25;
var monthImgWidth = 2;
var trackerVal = "none";
var displayDay = "9";
var displayMonth = "May";
var displayYear = "2007";
var prettyMonths = ["Jan","Feb","Mar","Apr","May","Jun","Jul","Aug","Sep","Oct","Nov","Dec"];

function showTrackers(val) {
	if(val == trackerVal) {
		return;
	}
	if(val == "inline") {
		document.getElementById("displayYearEl").style.color = "#ec008c";
		document.getElementById("displayMonthEl").style.color = "#ec008c";
		document.getElementById("displayDayEl").style.color = "#ec008c";		
	} else {
		document.getElementById("displayYearEl").innerHTML = displayYear;
		document.getElementById("displayYearEl").style.color = "#ff0";
		document.getElementById("displayMonthEl").innerHTML = displayMonth;
		document.getElementById("displayMonthEl").style.color = "#ff0";
		document.getElementById("displayDayEl").innerHTML = displayDay;
		document.getElementById("displayDayEl").style.color = "#ff0";
	}
   document.getElementById("wbMouseTrackYearImg").style.display = val;
   document.getElementById("wbMouseTrackMonthImg").style.display = val;
   trackerVal = val;
}
function getElementX2(obj) {
	var thing = jQuery(obj);
	if((thing == undefined) 
			|| (typeof thing == "undefined") 
			|| (typeof thing.offset == "undefined")) {
		return getElementX(obj);
	}
	return Math.round(thing.offset().left);
}
function trackMouseMove(event,element) {

   var eventX = getEventX(event);
   var elementX = getElementX2(element);
   var xOff = eventX - elementX;
	if(xOff < 0) {
		xOff = 0;
	} else if(xOff > imgWidth) {
		xOff = imgWidth;
	}
   var monthOff = xOff % yearImgWidth;

   var year = Math.floor(xOff / yearImgWidth);
	var yearStart = year * yearImgWidth;
   var monthOfYear = Math.floor(monthOff / monthImgWidth);
   if(monthOfYear > 11) {
       monthOfYear = 11;
   }
   // 1 extra border pixel at the left edge of the year:
   var month = (year * 12) + monthOfYear;
   var day = 1;
	if(monthOff % 2 == 1) {
		day = 15;
	}
	var dateString = 
		zeroPad(year + firstYear) + 
		zeroPad(monthOfYear+1,2) +
		zeroPad(day,2) + "000000";

	var monthString = prettyMonths[monthOfYear];
	document.getElementById("displayYearEl").innerHTML = year + 1996;
	document.getElementById("displayMonthEl").innerHTML = monthString;
	// looks too jarring when it changes..
	//document.getElementById("displayDayEl").innerHTML = zeroPad(day,2);

	var url = wbPrefix + dateString + '/' +  wbCurrentUrl;
	document.getElementById('wm-graph-anchor').href = url;

   //document.getElementById("wmtbURL").value="evX("+eventX+") elX("+elementX+") xO("+xOff+") y("+year+") m("+month+") monthOff("+monthOff+") DS("+dateString+") Moy("+monthOfYear+") ms("+monthString+")";
   if(curYear != year) {
       var yrOff = year * yearImgWidth;
       document.getElementById("wbMouseTrackYearImg").style.left = yrOff + "px";
       curYear = year;
   }
   if(curMonth != month) {
       var mtOff = year + (month * monthImgWidth) + 1;
       document.getElementById("wbMouseTrackMonthImg").style.left = mtOff + "px";
       curMonth = month;
   }
}
//]]]] ><![CDATA[>
]] ></script><style type="text/css"><![CDATA[body{margin-top:0!important;padding-top:0!important;min-width:800px!important;}#wm-ipp a:hover{text-decoration:underline!important;}]] ></style><div id="wm-ipp" lang="en" class="__wb_banner_div" style="display:none; position:relative;padding:0 5px;min-height:70px;min-width:800px">
